abstract.p: Cynthia Munro Pyle letter about May 27 article on war plays says America's taste in art embodies deeply escapist psychology (S)

block.p: Has Charles Isherwood been seeing too many productions from too great an emotional distance (possibly inevitable, when one must attend numerous plays each week)? Perhaps he has a proposal for a totally new theater: post-Aristotelian, postmodern, post-human?

Has Charles Isherwood been seeing too many productions from too great an emotional distance (possibly inevitable, when one must attend numerous plays each week)? Perhaps he has a proposal for a totally new theater: post-Aristotelian, postmodern, post-human?

He hints at escapist reasons for the failure of a remarkable and, yes, cathartic play, ''Journey's End,'' on Broadway, but the real clue lies in the fact that the play failed here ''after a long run in London.'' The British have as much reason to avoid thinking about war's realities. Can it be that the United States, founded by people escaping from religious and political persecution, embodies a deeply escapist psychology? That would explain this country's preference for escapist, even childish, film, theater, literature, music, art and politics.
